title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement dom.makowski@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Citing 'easystats'
text: reference easystats? Cite specific packages parsimonious approach cite particular package helped , e.g., “using bayestestR (Makowski, Ben-Shachar, & Lüdecke, 2019)”. Cite whole ecosystem ❤️ Want credit whole easystats ecosystem packages? can done sentence like following: Data processing carried R (R Core Team, 2019) easystats ecosystem (Lüdecke, Waggoner, & Makowski, 2019; Lüdecke, Ben-Shachar, Patil, Waggoner, & Makowski, 2021; Makowski, Ben-Shachar, & Lüdecke, 2019; Makowski, Ben-Shachar, Patil, & Lüdecke, 2020; Lüdecke, Ben-Shachar, Patil, & Makowski, 2020; Lüdecke et al., 2021; Ben-Shachar, Lüdecke, & Makowski, 2020) Lüdecke, D., Waggoner, P. D., & Makowski, D. (2019). insight: Unified Interface Access Information Model Objects R. Journal Open Source Software, 4, 1412. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01412 Makowski, D., Ben-Shachar, M.S., & Lüdecke, D. (2019). bayestestR: Describing Effects Uncertainty, Existence Significance within Bayesian Framework. Journal Open Source Software, 4(40), 1541. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01541 Makowski, D., Ben-Shachar, M.S., Patil, ., & Lüdecke, D. (2019). Methods Algorithms Correlation Analysis R. Journal Open Source Software, 5(51), 2306. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02306 Lüdecke, D., Ben-Shachar, M.S., Patil, ., & Makowski, D. (2020). parameters: Extracting, Computing Exploring Parameters Statistical Models using R. Journal Open Source Software, 5(53), 2445. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02445 Ben-Shachar, M.S., Lüdecke, D., Makowski, D. (2020). effectsize: Estimation Effect Size Indices Standardized Parameters. Journal Open Source Software, 5(56), 2815. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02815 Lüdecke, D., Ben-Shachar, M.S., Patil, ., Waggoner, P. D., & Makowski, D. (2021). performance: R Package Assessment, Comparison Testing Statistical Models. Journal Open Source Software, 6(60), 3139. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.03139 Lüdecke, D., Patil, ., Ben-Schachar, M.S., Wiernik, B.M., Waggoner, P., & Makowski, D. (2021). see: R Package Visualizing Statistical Models. Journal Open Source Software, 6(64), 3393, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.03393 Click see corresponding APA bibtex entries
code: @article{ludecke2019insight,     journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},     doi = {10.21105/joss.01412},     issn = {2475-9066},     number = {38},     publisher = {The Open Journal},     title = {insight: A Unified Interface to Access Information from Model Objects in R},     url = {http://dx.doi.org/10.21105/joss.01412},     volume = {4},     author = {Lüdecke, Daniel and Waggoner, Philip and Makowski, Dominique},     pages = {1412},     date = {2019-06-25},     year = {2019},     month = {6},     day = {25} }   @article{makowski2019bayestestr,     title = {{bayestestR}: {Describing} {Effects} and their {Uncertainty}, {Existence} and {Significance} within the {Bayesian} {Framework}},     volume = {4},     issn = {2475-9066},     shorttitle = {{bayestestR}},     url = {https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.01541},     doi = {10.21105/joss.01541},     number = {40},     urldate = {2019-08-13},     journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},     author = {Makowski, Dominique and Ben-Shachar, Mattan S. and Lüdecke, Daniel},     month = aug,     year = {2019},     pages = {1541} }  @article{makowski2020correlation,   doi={10.21105/joss.02306},   title={Methods and Algorithms for Correlation Analysis in R},   author={Makowski, Dominique and Ben-Shachar, Mattan S. and Patil, Indrajeet and L{\"u}decke, Daniel},   journal={Journal of Open Source Software},   volume={5},   number={51},   pages={2306},   year={2020} }  @article{ludecke20202parameters,   title = {parameters: Extracting, Computing and Exploring the Parameters of Statistical Models using {R}.},   volume = {5},   doi = {10.21105/joss.02445},   number = {53},   journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},   author = {Daniel Lüdecke and Mattan S. Ben-Shachar and Indrajeet Patil and Dominique Makowski},   year = {2020},   pages = {2445}, }  @article{benchashar2020effectsize,   title = {{e}ffectsize: Estimation of Effect Size Indices and Standardized Parameters},   author = {Mattan S. title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: Note generated random number 0 1 using rnorm() function (specifying want one number using n argument), stored inside variable called x (using assignment operator <-, kinda similar = languages). also commented steps using hash symbol #, can write things help us remember / explain steps.
code: x <- rnorm(n = 1) # Generate n=1 random number x # Display it > [1] -0.083

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: Note condition (x > 0.5) must place round brackets, whereas code chunks ifs elses curly brackets {}. “grammar” important R understand want .
code: x <- rnorm(n = 1)  if (x > 0.5) {   print("Yes!") } else {   print("No :(") } > [1] "Yes!"

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: Similarly majority programming languages, one can define functions R. like little factories take input, something, return output.

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: function can defined like : named function f(), written anything (long spaces), my_new_function(). , place-holder input, named x (, named anything). last important thing know returned function last object function, case x + 1. based , understand function defined equivalent one: Notice last line function, just contains final object want return (named “output”). Finally, adding comments super useful explain remember step .
code: f <- function(x) {   x + 1 }  f(3) > [1] 4 my_function <- function(first_argument) {   output <- first_argument + 1 # Make addition   output # Return the stuff }  my_function(3) > [1] 4

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: function often multiple arguments (“input” variables). used function like bubble, inside (aka local scope) knowledge “outside world” (called global scope). anything want know “outside” (instance, things user can interact) must entered arguments. , user must specify values , b should_we_add. added conditional statement inside function, different things done one argument (should_we_add) certain value (TRUE FALSE). However, functions R default arguments, .e., values associated arguments, changed users specifies otherwise. function written follows: difference function definition (round brackets write arguments), argument default value. means user don’t manually specifies argument, use default ones. ’s output f2() (without anything) f2(2, 3, TRUE).
code: f2 <- function(a, b, should_we_add) {   y <- a * b   if (should_we_add == TRUE) {     z <- y + 3   } else {     z <- y - 3   }   z }  f2(2, 3, TRUE) > [1] 9 f2 <- function(a = 2, b = 3, should_we_add = TRUE) {   y <- a * b   if (should_we_add == TRUE) {     z <- y + 3   } else {     z <- y - 3   }   z }  f2() > [1] 9

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: nutshell, R, things look like. means objects often “shown” (’ll come back --shown later). Let’s load iris dataset example examine . dataframe, gets displayed follows: object information attached , displayed. “additional” information stored attributes, retrieved follows: attributes take form list elements, like column names, row names … class name. R, class object corresponds written class attribute. can retrieve directly running class() function. modify (.e., overwrite) class attribute, let’s see happens try display : gets displayed weirdly! “displaying” object R… actually runs method (print method), method defined new class. showed purest “raw” form. now, let us remember don’t usually replace class, simply add (append) new one list, like c("new_class", other_classes). ’s objects can number classes. can see class now list (specifically, vector) classes. object object class "new_class" object class “data.frame”. method found first class, try second. Let’s see gets displayed now: Now, gets displayed correctly , also dataframe, can run print method dataframes (part R ).

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: Let’s assemble everything know create objects different classes: Although one different class, objects remain ‘numeric’ class. means method works ‘numeric’ work objects, square root:
code: f_a <- function(x) {   output <- x * 2   class(output) <- c("class_a", class(output))   output } f_a(3) > [1] 6 > attr(,"class") > [1] "class_a" "numeric" f_b <- function(x) {   output <- x * 3   class(output) <- c("class_b", class(output))   output } f_b(3) > [1] 9 > attr(,"class") > [1] "class_b" "numeric" sqrt(f_b(3)) > [1] 3 > attr(,"class") > [1] "class_b" "numeric"

title: Contributing to R Packages: A Tutorial
text: Methods pretty much defined like functions, twist. First, name method must added method using UseMethod() function, tell R method. , methods defined using name_of_method.name_of_class pattern. write name class dot following name method. tells R function use depending class first argument. method two classes defined follows: can now run new_method() two functions see something different.  ’s . ’s R ecosystem made! packages define mostly new classes, like statistical models , packages (like easystats broom) provide new methods interact objects.
code: new_method <- function(x) {   UseMethod("new_method") }  new_method.class_a <- function(x) {   text <- "This is an object of class A"   text }  new_method.class_b <- function(x) {   text <- "This is an object of class B"   text } new_method(f_a(3)) > [1] "This is an object of class A" new_method(f_b(3)) > [1] "This is an object of class B"

Ideally, packages work unison cover aspects statistical analysis data visualization. report: 📜 🎉 Automated statistical reporting objects R correlation: 🔗 --one package run correlations modelbased: 📈 Estimate effects, group averages contrasts groups based statistical models bayestestR: 👻 Great beginners experts Bayesian statistics parameters: 📊 Obtain table containing information parameters models performance: 💪 Models’ quality performance metrics (R2, ICC, LOO, AIC, BF, …) effectsize: 🐉 Compute, convert, interpret work indices effect size standardized parameters insight: 🔮 developers, package help work different models packages see: 🎨 plotting companion create beautiful results visualizations datawizard: 🧙 Magic potions clean transform data

title: Jump in the Easyverse
text: easystats different tidyverse? ’ve probably already heard tidyverse, another popular collection packages (ggplot, dplyr, tidyr, …) also makes using R easier. , pick tidyverse easystats? Pick ! Indeed, two ecosystems designed different goals mind. tidyverse packages primarily made create new R experience, data manipulation exploration intuitive consistent. hand, easystats focuses final stretch analysis: understanding interpreting results reporting manuscript report, following best practices. can definitely use easystats functions tidyverse workflow! easystats + tidyverse = ❤️ Can easystats useful advanced users /developers? Yes, definitely! easystats built terms modules general enough used inside packages. instance, insight package made easily implement support post-processing pretty much regression model packages sun. use easystats packages, also used non-easystats packages, ggstatsplot, modelsummary, ggeffects, . ? Moreover, easystats packages lightweight, minimal set dependencies, makes great want rely .
